comments.body: It seems like we'd leak the forwarding rule/target pool on GKE without some cleanup here.
Testing seems to indicate this is not needed for GKE. I'll double check.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +41,45 @@    local REGION=${ZONE%-*}
    if [[ "${KUBERNETES_PROVIDER}" == "gce" ]]; then
      gcloud compute forwarding-rules delete -q --project="${PROJECT}" --region ${REGION} "${INSTANCE_PREFIX}-default-frontend" || true
      gcloud compute target-pools delete -q --project="${PROJECT}" --region ${REGION} "${INSTANCE_PREFIX}-default-frontend" || true
    fi

comments.body: Just because pods are in the running state doesn't mean the docker pulls have finished and that the application is ready to serve. Would it be more reliable to do a loop around a get from the frontend service which might be a better signal that the e2e test should proceed.
Is it possible to do a WATCH here rather than a poll?
@satnam6502 Is it possible to watch from command line?

I am not sure, hence the question mark in my comment. I assume we can get an HTTP GET /watch/resource-name ? Perhaps that is not so convenient here. Anyway, this is a very minor point and what you do here is very representative of what we do elsewhere. I'm thinking of changing some of our Go e2e tests that have poll loops with WATCH calls but here I think it is perhaps more convenient to poll and wait.
Sorry. I've thought it was a suggestion;)

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +47,51 @@    for pod in $pods; do
      status=$(${KUBECTL} get pods $pod -o template '--template={{.currentState.status}}') || true
      if [[ "$status" == "Pending" ]]; then
        all_running=0
        break

comments.body: kubectl -f can act on entire directories? I had no idea...
Yup. It looks for file extensions that could be schemas and attempts to load them as resources (skipping if invalid schema).

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +36,40 @@prepare-e2e

GUESTBOOK="${KUBE_ROOT}/examples/guestbook"

echo "WARNING: this test is a no op that only attempts to launch guestbook resources."
